description: From Old French harpon, from Latin harpaga, a rare variant of Latin harpagō, from Ancient Greek ἁρπάγη (harpágē, “hook”), from ἁρπάζω (harpázō, “to snatch away, to carry off, to seize, to captivate”). Sense and spelling perhaps influenced by Dutch harpoen (“harpoon”). Doublet of harpagon.

entries.meaning: A spearlike weapon with a barbed head used in hunting whales and large fish.

verbs.description: harpoon (third-person singular simple present harpoons, present participle harpooning, simple past and past participle harpooned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shoot something with a harpoon.
